item.content:encoded:
TW/CW: Mentions of war.

I can’t recall a time when my family celebrated “Liberation Day”.

I can recall times that we volunteered at the Sons & Daughters of Guam Club for Liberation fiestas: cleaning, cooking, setting up & breaking down, etc…but being young, I wasn’t interested in the “whys” of fiestas.

But celebrating at home? T친ya'.

I’m positive there’s complexities behind that. I mean, growing up I only ever heard one story about the war from my dad’s mom. It was a quick story, maybe 5 minutes in length, and it ended with her grasping one hand into the other, remembering the pain she felt as a young child from grabbing a freshly-ejected bullet casing that landed near her yan i che’lu-침a as they hid gi papa' trongkon nunu.

As I write now, I’m reminded of how much history my grandparents didn’t pass down. Stories of their childhood, their upbringing, their families, their homes; stories I’ll likely never know. Estoria siha na ni ngai’an hu hunguk'.

But I get it, I really do.

My grandparents were 5-13 years old when this all happened, and it happened damn near in their front yards. The same soil that they walked to church on would become littered with imprints of combat boots in years to come. I try to imagine a boisterous chicken coop or two behind my grandpa’s house, but the imagined memory fades into silence…and then into booms and explosions.

Why would my grandparents want to relive those memories? So I get it, I really do.

And despite all that they had been through, when the time came both my grandpas turned to the U.S. Navy. Maybe they felt they owed it to the U.S. - for the “Liberation” they had received. I have no knowledge of how they came to those decisions, but they made them. And as I sit here in a comfy chair, in an air-conditioned house, where my parents can watch their grandchild respond to me as hu fino' Chamoruyi gui'…ya si침a ha komprendi yu'?…well, I certainly can’t blame them - at least I don’t want to. They did what they thought was best.

T친ya' nai na hu silebra esti na ha’친ni. Ya ti hu tungu' yanggen bai cho’gui' ennao. What I can and will do is give thanks to i manamko'-ta ni' manl친’la' dur친nten i gera. They were forced into an impossible situation and forced to make difficult decisions. Decisions with ramifications still echoing today.

So I’ll end this not with an exclamation of joy, sa' para gu친hu, ti minagof esti na ha’친ni. Rather, it is a memorial day. A reminder of the courage and tenacity of our people. A reminder that we are still here, fighting for real liberation; for a decolonized status; for independence.

Fanohgi. Fanachu. Na’l친’la'.

Todu ha' para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya. — DJT.

On my side of the family we tend to split time between my dad’s side and my mom’s side. Even then, those parties tend to be closer to New Years or after, i.e., my family tends to celebrate Christmas after New Years — ya maolek-침a i “sales” dispues di New Years ki antes, hunggan? 游땐

Guaha bula hinasso-ku siha ginen tiempon Krismas yan i famili친-ku. It was definitely one of the happiest times of the year for me: bula nengk친nnu', gaigi todu mamprim친-hu gi gima', ya mang친nta yan manmanayuyut ham. Mah친lang yu' nu eyu tiempu.

Si침a hu hunguk eyu na k친nta siha trabiha…: Fanm친tto Manhengge, Kant친yi Gui', O Patgon Belen, etc… Hearing them sing those songs inundated me with memories and I found myself wishing I had spent more time cherishing those moments; wishing I had pictures or footage; wishing my grandma was still alive and we could do i Nobenan Ni침o just one more time.

Hu tungu' na si침a hu bisita otro taotao ni' ma침ilebra i Nobenan Ni침o, lao ti parehu eyu yanggen taigui i famili친-ku. Ohala na gumaigi yu' yan i ma침ain친-hu lamo’na. Mah친lang yu' nu siha.
